1:
Do you know at what time the wild goats in the rocks bear their young?\q Can you watch when the deer are having their fawns?
\q
2:
Can you count the months that they gestate?\q Do you know the time when they bear their young?


\q
3:
They crouch down and birth their young,\q and then they finish their labor pains.
\q
4:
Their young ones become strong and grow up in the open fields;\q they go out and do not come back again.
\m


\q
5:
Who let the wild donkey go free?\q Who has untied the bonds of the swift donkey,
\q
6:
whose home I have made in the Arabah,\q his house in the salt land?

\q
7:
He laughs in scorn at the noises in the city;\q he does not hear the driver's shouts.
\q
8:
He roams over the mountains as his pastures;\q there he looks for every green plant to eat.


\q
9:
Will the wild ox be happy to serve you?\q Will he consent to stay by your manger?
\q
10:
With a rope, can you control the wild ox to plow the furrows?\q Will he harrow the valleys for you?


\q
11:
Will you trust him because his strength is great?\q Will you leave your work to him to do?
\q
12:
Will you depend on him to bring your grain home,\q to gather the grain for your threshing floor?
\m


\q
13:
The wings of the ostrich wave proudly,\q but are they the pinions and plumage of love?
\q
14:
For she leaves her eggs on the earth,\q and she lets them keep warm in the dust;
\q
15:
she forgets that a foot might crush them\q or that a wild beast might trample them.


\q
16:
She deals roughly with her young ones as if they were not hers;\q she does not fear that her labor might have been in vain,
\q
17:
because God has deprived her of wisdom\q and has not given her any understanding.
\q
18:
When she runs swiftly,\q she laughs in scorn at the horse and its rider.
\m


\q
19:
Have you given the horse his strength?\q Did you clothe his neck with his flowing mane?
\q
20:
Have you ever made him jump like a locust?\q The majesty of his snorting is fearsome.


\q
21:
He paws in might and rejoices in his strength;\q he rushes out to meet the weapons.
\q
22:
He mocks fear and is not dismayed;\q he does not turn back from the sword.
\q
23:
The quiver rattles against his flank,\q along with the flashing spear and the javelin.


\q
24:
He swallows up ground with fierceness and rage;\q at the trumpet's sound, he cannot stand in one place.
\q
25:
Whenever the trumpet sounds, he says, 'Aha!'\q He smells the battle from far awayâ€”
\q the thunderous shouts of the commanders and the outcries.
\m


\q
26:
Is it by your wisdom that the hawk soars,\q that he stretches out his wings for the south?


\q
27:
Is it at your orders that the eagle mounts up\q and makes his nest in high places?
\q
28:
He lives on cliffs and makes his home\q on the peaks of cliffs, a stronghold.


\q
29:
From there he searches for victims;\q his eyes see them from very far away.
\q
30: His young also drink up blood;\q where killed people are, there he is."
